Award.AwardTitle: RI: Small: Collaborative Research: Robustness of Spatial Learning in Flickering Networks: The Case of the Hippocampus

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The reliability of our memories is nothing short of remarkable. Thousands of neurons die every day, synaptic connections appear and disappear, and the networks formed by these neurons constantly change due to various forms of synaptic plasticity. How can the brain develop a reliable representation of the world, learn and retain memories despite, or perhaps due to, such complex dynamics? Answering such questions is the natural evolution of recent work by the Dabaghian lab, which has been studying spatial cognition by modeling mechanisms of learning, based on algebraic topology methods developed by the Memoli group. This approach rests on the insight that the animal brain must first construct a rough-and-ready map of the environment before being able to fill it in with geometric details, which would be too computationally costly in light of typical navigational goals such as evading predators, returning to a nest, or finding a cafe. This basic map pays particular attention to the connectivity between places in the environment and is thus based on spatial topology; as such, the investigators hypothesized, it would be amenable to analysis by topological methods.

By simulating exploratory movements through different environments Dabaghian and Memoli will study how stable topological features arise in assemblies of simulated neurons operating under a wide range of conditions, including variations in firing rate, the size of the space each cell "senses," the number of cells in the population, and electrical oscillations in the brain that alter the behavior of the ensemble. They will use several novel methods from Persistent Homology Theory to understand how connections between cells (synapses) influence the speed and reliability of spatial learning. One might assume that learning would be enhanced if synapses never disappeared, but biology has clearly evolved to favor great synaptic plasticity. One reason may be that the loss of certain connections allows more room for mistakes to be unlearned. The objectives of this project are to study synaptic plasticity in a computational model, which will allow the influences of different parameters on the outcome of learning to be studied in detail. Principles that emerge on spatial learning in the hippocampus should be translatable to spatial cognition in machines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mammalian hippocampus plays a key role in producing and sustaining memory frameworks. In particular, it creates an internalized representation of the ambient space—a cognitive map that serves as a basis of animals’ spatial awareness. The structure of this map and the mechanisms responsible for its appearance are widely studied all over the world for the last four decades, following the pioneering work of John O’Keefe who won the Nobel Prize for his discoveries in 2014.

Our research proposal, also dedicated to cognitive map studies, concentrated on a particular and yet principal question: how the hippocampal network may encode reliable spatial memories, given that the connections between the hippocampal neurons are transient, i.e., appear and disappear at a rapid rate? From a theoretical perspective, this inquiry addresses an even more general problem: it is well known that physiological networks in the brain are dynamic and yet we are perfectly capable of retaining memories of the external world for months and years. How can this work?

Answering this question involves addressing a wide scope of complex physiological phenomena and requires extensive research efforts from both theoretical and experimental sides. Our goal was to use computational modeling in order to achieve principal understanding of these phenomena that could later guide design of the experiments and hence obviate some of the more invasive animal studies (e.g., by minimizing use of animals), and in general optimize physical and intellectual resources.

To achieve this goal, we created a biologically realistic computational model of the hippocampal place cell assembly network with “flickering” synapses that incorporates a variety of physiological details. To achieve operational transparency, reliability and accuracy of modeling, we advanced in steps, starting from basic implementations and gradually worked our way to more elaborate representations that captured more and more biological specifics and lead us to deeper understating of the studied phenomena. In the end, we achieved our goal: we were able to demonstrate that rapidly rewiring neuronal networks can indeed encode stable representations of the world, as we hypothesized in our proposal. Moreover, we demonstrated that this is a generic effect that can be reliably established in various settings and under rather general assumptions, which implies that this “emergent stability” is a generic, “umbrella phenomenon” that can be implemented in networks with different synaptic architectures.

Our approach was powered by most advanced Algebraic Topology algorithms, in particular the novel Zigzag Homology Theory techniques (along with other algebraic topology concepts and tools), which we adopted to describing spatial information represented via a complex system of signals—neuronal spike trains (as opposed to traditional semantics of deterministic, “spatial” objects such as manifolds, their triangulations, etc.). To our knowledge, ZigZag homology theory is a unique mathematical apparatus that is ideally fit for investigating the flow of information through a network with flickering synaptic connections, thus providing an extremely useful interface between hippocampal neurophysiology and algebraic topology.

We therefore anticipate that our work will impact not only theoretical neuroscience but also applied mathematics, in particular computational topology and geometry. Understanding how networks with transient connections can gain, maintain and retrieve information could also have ramifications for computer learning.

The work was carried out to a large extent by a graduate student (Samir Chowdhury) and a postdoctoral fellow (Andrey Babichev), under direct supervision of the PIs. The PIs also worked with several undergraduate students, two of whom (K. Hoffman and E. Basso) became first authors on publications in reputable academic journals. Their research was funded in part by the REU awards associated with this grant, and both students continued their studies in graduate schools. During our work we established several new collaborations, notably we started a series of projects with Dr. Dmitriy Morozov (Lawrence Berkeley National Lab) who made a major contribution by devising and optimizing the software for computing ZigZag homologies.               

This work resulted in over a dozen publications and was presented at several key domestic and international conferences, including annual meetings of the American Physical Society (APS, San Antonio 2015, New Orleans 2017), Society for Neuroscience (SfN, Chicago 2015), Cognitive Neuroscience Society (CNS, San Francisco 2017); AIM workshops “Topology of the biomolecular world” (San Jose, 2017), and “Data Sciences: Bridging Mathematics, Physics and Biology” (Singapore, 2017), “Topological Methods in Brain Network Analysis” (Banff, Canada, 2017); Topological Data Analysis, Abel Symposium, 2018 (Geiranger, Norway 2018) and Algebraic Topology: Methods, Computation and Science (ATMCS8, IST Austria 2018), and multiple poster presentations.

Having accomplished the specific research goals of this proposal, our current goal is to extend this research program so that it incorporates not only theoretical but also experimental lines of research, involving collaboration with electrophysiological labs.
